newsitem.title: UK: Nelson output seen cut by 60,000 bpd -operator.
newsitem.headline: Nelson output seen cut by 60,000 bpd -operator.

text.p: Crude production from the North Sea Nelson field is likely to be cut back by around 60,000 barrels per day on Friday due to problems with the gas system, a spokesman for operator Enterprise Oil said.
He said production was currently running about 10,000 bpd down at 130,000 bpd, but needed to be cut to around 70,000 bpd to prevent excess gas flaring.
"It'll probably be a step change...it'll more than likely be today," the spokesman said.
The cut back is likely to last until the middle of next week, but the situation could change, he said.
Nelson feeds into the Forties system, but the details of adjustments to the July loading programme were not yet clear.
Enterprise said that due to a problem with the gas dehydration system, all gas produced at the Nelson field was currently being flared.
"We need to cut back production to prevent excess flaring which is not environmentally acceptable," said the spokesman.
"It's a hangover from the recent production shutdown," he added.
The field had to lower output to about 53,000 bpd in June to allow repairs to a faulty gas compressor.
Production was restored gradually to around 140,000 bpd late in June after the repair was completed. Full capacity is around 160,000 bpd.
